description: From Middle French frontispice, from Latin frontispicium, from frōns (“forehead”) + specere (“look at”). Spelling altered due to folk etymology, influenced by piece.

entries.meaning: (publishing) An illustration that is on the page before the title page of a book, a section of one, or a magazine.
(archaic, publishing) The title page of a book.
(architecture) A façade, especially an ornamental one.
(architecture) A small ornamental pediment, especially at the top of a window or door.

examples: He carries on his frontispiece the indubitable marks of a money-dealer. His is one of those peculiar faces  […]

verbs.description: frontispiece (third-person singular simple present frontispieces, present participle frontispiecing, simple past and past participle frontispieced)

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To supply with a frontispiece.
examples: The novel was frontispieced with a portrait of the author.
